greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array A(n,k) read by antidiagonals, A(n,n) = -n, otherwise, if n > k, A(n,k) = T(n-k,k), else A(n,k) = T(n,k-n), where T(n,k) is sequence A000027 considered as a two-dimensional table.
comment: The array is read by descending antidiagonals as A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), etc.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10585; the first 145 antidiagonals of the array
formula: If n = k, A(n,k) = -n, if n > k, A(n,k) = T(n-k,k), otherwise [when n < k], A(n,k) = T(n,k-n), where T(n,k) is sequence A000027 considered as a two-dimensional table, that is, as a pairing function from N X N to N.
example: The top left 14 X 14 corner of the array:
program: (define (A285732bi row col) (cond ((= row col) (- row)) ((> row col) (A000027bi (- row col) col)) (else (A000027bi row (- col row)))))
def T(n, m): return ((n + m)**2 - n - 3*m + 2)//2
def A(n, k): return -n if n == k else T(n - k, k) if n>k else T(n, k - n)
for n in range(1, 21): print([A(k, n - k + 1) for k in range(1, n + 1)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, May 03 2017
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, May 03 2017
